direction.raw_text: . Close on a hand opening an old cigar box. April is sitting with the box at the kitchen table. It contains various sentimental knickknacks from her past, including photos of the kids, of her and Frank in New York with friends, and a photograph of Frank in uniform beneath the Eifel tower on liberation day... She studies it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FLASHBACK Frank fixes coffee in the tiny kitchen. April is sitting up in bed in the first blue light of day wearing Frank's T-shirt. She holds a curled collection of black and white photographs in her lap. She stops on the same picture of Frank and the Eifel Tower. Frank comes over with the coffee, and two cigarettes.     He lights them both, and gives her one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lies down with his cigarette between his teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares up at the ceiling.    She studies him.   Appraising.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her, overwhelmed by her face in the light.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You ever been to Paris? APRIL I've never really been anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I'll take you with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going back first chance I get. People are alive there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I know now is that I want to feel things. Really feel them. How's that for an ambition...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frank Wheeler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you're the most interesting person I've ever met.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frank stands at the mantle tying his tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maureen covers herself with the sheets.

direction.raw_text: Frank inspects the contents of the mantle: photos of Maureen at the prom; Maureen with her parents. Maureen tentatively fingers her hair that has now gone to frizz. The sheet slips down. She grabs at it. Then wills herself to calm down and act sophisticated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and smiles at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes over and gives her one. Lights it with his Zippo. She exhales, slowly gaining confidence. Frank gets up and pulls on his jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes over to her.   Bends down, kisses her gently on the lips.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I guess this wasn't what you had in mind when you went to work this morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.   It certainly wasn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have a cigarette, Frank?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I get you a drink or anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks, Maureen. Actually, I guess I'd better be cutting out, it's getting kind of late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gee, that's right.   Have you missed your train?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right, I'll get the next one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen: you were swell. Take care now.

direction.raw_text: . Frank approaches the door with his key. He takes a moment to gather himself, but before he can, the door opens. April is dressed in a black cocktail dress. She looks wonderful. She smiles. She steps forward and takes his face in her hands. She kisses him.

dialogue.raw_text: Frank...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First of all, I missed you all day and I want to say I'm sorry. I'm sorry for the way I've been since that stupid play. I'm sorry for everything and... And I love you... Now wait here till I call you. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (CONT'D) Alright Frank! You can come in now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and April sit around the table wearing paper birthday crowns. They sing Happy Birthday.

direction.raw_text: . He turns off the water.   He stands there in the silence, regaining control.

direction.raw_text: Frank laughs again.

dialogue.raw_text: Frank. I have had the most wonderful idea. I've been thinking about it all day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's all this about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know how much money we have saved...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enough to live on for six months without you earning another dime. And with the money we could get from the house and the car, longer than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What we get for the house...What are you talking about? Where are we going to live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Paris.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You always said it was the only place you'd ever been that was worth living. So why don't we go there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.   What's stopping us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's stopping us? Well, I can think of a lot of things. For instance, what kind of a job could I possibly get?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't be getting any kind of job, because I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't laugh -- listen a minute! Have you any idea what they pay for secretarial positions in the government agencies in Europe? Embassies and those things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't. APRIL I'm serious about this Frank. Do you think I'm kidding or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I know, I know. I just have a couple of questions, is all. For one thing, do you mind telling me what exactly I'm supposed to be doing while you're out earning all this money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you see that's the whole idea? You'll be doing what you should've been allowed to do seven years ago. You'll have time, Frank. You'll have time to find out what it is that you actually want to do, and when you figure it out you'll have the time and the freedom to start doing it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sweetheart, it's just not very realistic, is all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I happen to think this is unrealistic. I think it's unrealistic for a man with a fine mind to go on working like a dog year after year at a job he can't stand, coming home to a place he can't stand, to a wife who's equally unable to stand the same things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to know the worst part? Our whole existence here is based on this great premise that we're somehow very special and superior to the whole thing, and you know what I've realized...? We're not! We're just like everyone else. Look at us!   We've bought into the same ridiculous delusion. This idea that you have to resign from life and settle down the moment you have children. And we've been punishing each other for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen: we decided to move out here. No one ever forced me to take the job at Knox. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean who ever said I was supposed to be a big deal, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I first met you, there was nothing in the world you couldn't do or be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was a little wise guy with a big mouth, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were not! How can you even say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...All right... So, I'll have time. And God knows that's appealing. It's very appealing. And I mean, everything you say might make a certain amount of sense, if I had some definite talent maybe. If I were an artist or a writer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Frank, listen to me: It's what you are that's being stifled here. It's what you are that's being denied and denied and denied in this kind of life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you know...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the most valuable and wonderful thing in the world... You're a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is our chance, Frank.   This is our one chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not...? Why the hell not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frank is standing leaning against a coffee bar in Grand Central Station. He is finishing a beer. It is rush hour, and amidst the sea of people, he is the only one not moving. He is watching all the people walking by with an air of detached amusement. As if he were now above them all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Frank rides between train cars. The wind whips his hair. He takes a deep pull from a pinched cigarette - then flicks it straight as a bullet into the passing countryside. He feels alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The commuter train slows into the station. A door swings open. And Frank leaps from the still moving train onto the platform. He slows to a walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The kids dance back and forth through the sprinkler, shrieking with pleasure. April sits on the steps in front of the house reading some material from the American Express office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She looks up as Frank's car pulls into the drive. He steps out of the car and comes towards her. She looks up and smiles. He drops his brief case on the ground and walks towards her. She meets him in the middle of the lawn, and they embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP - two fingers walk the journey from New York to Paris across the page of an atlas. Michael and Jennifer, dressed for bed, sit sandwiched between April and Frank under the bedclothes.

direction.raw_text: A pause as the two kids stare at the Atlas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank senses that they are a little concerned.   April and Frank look to one another.

direction.raw_text: The children dissolve into disgusted laughter.    April and Frank laugh with them.

dialogue.raw_text: ...All the way to... here.

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles)

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . April paces the family room. Her hair is a defiant mess. She still wears her bathing suit under her clothes. Frank sits on the couch. The windows are open, and most of the lights are off. It's a very hot night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shakes his head and gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She disgustedly twists out her cigarette, and immediately lights another.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to go, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, April.   Of course I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't! Because you've never tried at anything. And if you don't try at anything you can't fail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell do you    mean I don't try? I support you,     don't I? I pay for this house.     I work ten hours a day at a job    I can't stand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bullshit! I'm not happy about it. But I have the backbone not to run away from my responsibilities!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It takes backbone to lead the life you want, Frank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it alright with you if I go to the bathroom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Frank splashes water on his face like a boxer between rounds. He looks up at his reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He reaches for a towel, but there isn't one. He turns to the shelf behind him and pulls down a fresh towel. Something catches his eye. He reaches to the back and retrieves a small brown paper package. He opens it, his face slowly registering what it means...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . April wheels around as - Frank storms in, a rubber syringe in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes at her across the room with the syringe in his hand. She moves away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shakes it in her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank turns towards her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April turns to the book shelves.   Her back to him. Frank waits, his heart beating quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eyes are bright with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Everything hangs on Frank's answer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April closes her eyes. Tears run down her cheeks.   He walks over to her, but he doesn't touch her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She cries quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns to face him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are you going to do with this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do you think you're going to do? You're going to stop me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're damn right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead and try!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen. Listen to me. You do this - you do this and I swear to God I'll - APRIL You'll what? You'll leave me?   Is that a threat, or a promise?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did you buy this, April?   I want to know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know you really are being melodramatic about the whole thing. As long as it's done in the first twelve weeks, it's perfectly safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's now April!   Don't I get a say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course you do! It would be for you, Frank, don't you see? So you can have time. Like we talked about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can it be for me if the thought makes my stomach turn over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then it's for me... Tell me we can have the baby in Paris, Frank. But don't make me stay here. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can't have the baby in Paris.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? I don't need everything we have here. I don't care where we live! I mean who made these rules, anyway? The only reason we moved out here was because I got pregnant. Then we had another child to prove the first one wasn't a mistake. I mean how long does it go on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frank. Do you actually want another child? Well, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, tell me. Tell me the truth, Frank. Remember that? We used to live by it. You know what's so good about the truth? Everyone knows what it is, however long they've lived without it. No one forgets the truth, Frank, they just get better at lying. So tell me: do you really want another child?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I know is what I feel. And anyone else in their right mind would feel the same way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quiet) But I've had two children.    Doesn't that count in my favor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christ! The fact that you even put it that way! You make it sound like having children is a punishment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love my children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're sure about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is that supposed to mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: April, you just said our daughter was mistake. How do I know you didn't try to get rid of her, or Michael for that matter? How do I know you didn't try to flush our entire fucking family down the toilet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No that's not true. Of course I didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But how do I know April?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop.   Please just stop, Frank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: April, a normal woman, a normal sane mother doesn't buy herself a piece of rubber tubing to give herself an abortion so she can, go live out some God damn fantasy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sober) All I'm saying is you don't seem entirely rational about this thing... And maybe we should get someone to help you think about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And the new job's going to pay for that too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: April if you need a shrink, it'll be paid for. Obviously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Okay. I guess there isn't much more to say, then, is there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I guess Paris was a pretty childish idea, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess maybe it was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can be happy here April...   I can make you happy here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've had a great few months.   It doesn't have to end...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope so Frank.   I really hope so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Frank stands at the picture window watching... April approach the children. She squats on the ground so she can be at their height and talks to them. Michael tries to get into her arms. Jennifer turns away and walks sulkily across the grass. Frank looks into his coffee cup.   He doesn't look like a man who won an argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Frank sits smoking nervously in an oak-paneled waiting room. The door opens behind him. He gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He follows her through the door.    The door closes behind her. We see the scene in dumb-show through the glass door. Bart looks up as Frank enters. An "I knew it all along" smile spreads across Pollock's face. He offers his hand to Frank. Frank smiles thinly. They shake.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for waiting.   Mr. Pollock can see you now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S) Foiled by faulty contraception.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Frank, Ed, Vince and Jack sit in the same booth in the same crowded luncheonette. Frank stares out the window.   The others can't contain themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his glass, drinks alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank looks away from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank glares with barely contained fury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed and Vince chuckle.   Frank's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't say I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't have been the same without you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd have been sorely missed in the old cubicle, I can tell you that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides which...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Well, the plan always seemed a touch unrealistic, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose, it's none of my business, really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.   I suppose it isn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we won't be the only ones glad to hear the news. They'll be celebrating in the secretarial pool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Two drumsticks spinning in a spotlight.   They click out a rhythm, and crash into a number. Cut back to reveal a small, low-ceilinged joint. On-stage are the Steve Kovack quartet, four perspiring middle-aged men with day jobs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and the odd middle-aged COUPLE navigate the dance floor. A smattering of lost SINGLES line the bar. The Wheelers and Campbells sit squashed into a booth on the side of the dance floor. Several empty glasses have accumulated. Milly is beating the edge of the table with red drink straws. She's a few drinks ahead. They have to SHOUT over the MUSIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They laugh at the old joke.   Then Milly begins to weep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She knocks her drink back.    The number finishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April stares out at the dance floor.    Frank looks at her.   A new number starts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Milly takes him by the hand and pulls him away. Shep and April watch. Then Shep turns his attention to April.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Frank turns his attention to Milly. He's a good dancer. His movements are fast and aggressive, his mind on April. Milly is a little too drunk, and hurries to keep up, perspiring through her dress. He spins her around and around, back and forth into his arms. Milly begins to look slightly dizzy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't hear her over the music, or he doesn't care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her body spasms with the need to be sick. She turns and rushes for the lady's room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Remember the first time you brought us here? You said, it takes a special kind of taste to enjoy Vito's Log Cabin!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's so awful it's kinda nice!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dabs at her eyes) Look at me...! I'm just so happy. Our little gang's back together again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least Europe's not going anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wanna dance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't really feel like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll dance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tipsy) Guess April's pretty blue `bout Paris, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think she'll be okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, sure. Give us girls a couple of days and we can get over anything!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Frank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frank... I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sudden remorse) You okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gee...I'm afraid I'm not very...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Frank leads the way through the cars. Shep supports Milly who is now falling down drunk. April walks alone a few paces behind... They reach Shep's car, which is trapped behind several other cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.   Frank looks to April.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank holds April's look an instant, then walks away with car keys in hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of all the inconsiderate...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look - why don't you take Milly home, then go home yourself and that would take care of both sitters. Then Shep can take me home later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to April) You'll be alright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Steve Kovack performs an exhausting, sweat-drenched drum solo. April and Shep now sit alone in the booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April distantly nods her thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shep sips his beer, trying to figure out how to connect with her...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shep nods, not entirely sure what she means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a long slug of her drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April doesn't hear, she's pursuing her thought...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April turns and stares at him. The band strikes up a new number.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry you're not going away anymore. I know it was important to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't take this wrong; I've been there and...they don't have so much we don't have here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It didn't have to be Paris.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just wanted out, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted in. I just wanted us to live again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For years I thought we shared a secret...that we would be wonderful in the world. I didn't exactly know how, but just the possibility...kept me hoping.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How pathetic is that? To put all your hopes in a promise that was never made? See, Frank knows...he knows what he wants. He's found his place. He's just fine. Married, two kids. It should be enough. It is for him. He's right; we were never special or destined or anything at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure you are. You're The Wheelers. You're a terrific couple, everyone says so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw a different life. I can't stop seeing it. (beat) Can't leave, can't stay. (beat) No damn use to anyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, let's do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . April and Shep dance. Shep can't dance well, but he's trying. April, on the other hand, is a wonderful dancer. She dances out as far as their joined hands allow and does a little twitching, hip-bobbing curtsies before twisting back, all seemingly effortless. It is joyous, released.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Shep slips behind the wheel and is immediately kissing her, groping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She climbs into the back seat. He pulls off his jacket and climbs in after her. He folds the jacket under her head for a pillow... She remains perfectly still, allowing him to kiss her, to search under her clothing, to kiss her skin and finally, to lift her skirt and pull her clothing aside and make love to her against the vinyl seat cover... As suddenly as it began, it's over. Shep collapses against her. April stares into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They begin to quietly assemble themselves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let me take you somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Please. Here.    Now.    In the back seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: April... This is what I've always wanted... I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't say that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean it, I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, just be quiet for a minute, then you can take me home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frank stands at the mirror putting on a clean shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . April stands at the kitchen table chopping vegetables.    She wears an unflattering floral dress. Frank stands in the doorway watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at the calendar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks over to her.   He takes her in his arms.   She stiffens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She looks him straight in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls herself free of his grasp. He watches as she adds the vegetables in the pot on the stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles patiently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's utterly uninterested and it's making him nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She continues folding the napkins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, she stops moving.   She looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is suddenly unsure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries that same patient smile, but it's not convincing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is frighteningly calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His panic mounts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes back into the kitchen. Frank follows her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank and April stare at each other, breathless.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's beautiful out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes; it's lovely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what today is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's twelve weeks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, this has been kind of a crazy summer. We've both been under a strain. I mean I know you're upset.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know I'm not sleeping with you and you want to know why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm sorry Frank, but I don't really feel like talking about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. What do you feel like talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would it be all right if we didn't talk about anything? Can't we just take each day as it comes, and do the best we can, and not feel we have to talk about everything all the time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I suggested we talk about everything all the time. My point was, we've both been under a strain and we ought to be trying to help each other as much as we can right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean God knows my own behavior has been pretty weird lately... I mean, as it happens... there is actually something I'd like to tell you about...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been with a girl in the city a few times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A girl I hardly even know. It was nothing to me, but she got a little carried away. She's just a kid... Anyway, it's over now. It's really over. If I weren't sure of that I guess I could never have told you about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (relieved) Baby, I don't know. I think it was a simple case of wanting to be a man again after all that abortion business. Some kind of neurotic, irrational need to prove something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I don't mean why did you have the girl; I mean why did you tell me about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean what's the point? Is it supposed to make me jealous, or something? Is it supposed to make me fall in love with you, or back into bed with you, or what? I mean what am I supposed to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you say what you feel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't feel anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In other words you don't care what I do or who I fuck or anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No; I guess that's right; I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck who you like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you see...Don't you see, I want you to care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I know you do. And I suppose I would if I loved you. But you see I don't think I do anymore. And I only just figured that out. And that's why I'd just as soon not do any talking right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, now don't give me this shit! You know God damn well you love me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think so?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know GOD DAMN WELL!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS (O.S.) Yoo-hoo!   Any one home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Frank and the Givings' sit with cocktails. It's painfully awkward. Moving boxes are everywhere. APRIL I'm sorry dinner's late. Can I get anyone a refill?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank looks at April. She avoids his look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John looks up. Frank looks at April.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April manages a forced smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fixes Frank with the stare of a prosecuting attorney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John holds up a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John paces the room, with his hands behind his back like a detective at a murder scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns the force of his smile on April.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks across the room and stabs out her cigarette.   Then immediately lights another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He swings around to face Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank stares back defiantly.   Rage bubbling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John holds up his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank stares at John, his rage increasing.   Mr. Givings gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lets out his braying laugh.   April starts to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April stares at Frank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Givings moves John towards the door. Mrs. Givings slowly stands. April is the only one left seated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He winks at April and puts his hat on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: April's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frank lunges at John. Mr. Givings tries to hold Frank back. Mrs. Givings leaps between them. She's crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.   Mr. Givings slowly releases Frank.   He is breathing heavily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He guides him from the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes another step towards the door, then stops and turns back, laughing again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points a yellow-stained finger at April's stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go out. Frank goes to the liquor cabinet, pours a whiskey and drinks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . April watches him from across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to April.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes towards her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him.    Then she begins to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reels around the room, her laughter increasingly out of control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a step towards her. All the laughter goes out of her face.   She backs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes her by the arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She SCREAMS. High and shrill.    Her eyes wide open, cold and perfectly calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slips past him. He goes after her. She pulls a chair into his path. He SLINGS it against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins to shake with anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points at her belly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strides out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS Oh, don't worry. It's nice just to sit for a bit and socialize...You really didn't need to go through all the trouble of cooking. I can see you have a lot to do with packing and what not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, there's been a change of plans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS Oh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought maybe it was obvious... April's pregnant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS Oh, April! I can't tell you how pleased I am. Oh, but I expect you'll be needing a bigger house, now, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it a second, Ma.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't get this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so obvious about it? I mean okay, she's pregnant; so what? Don't people have babies in Europe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS Oh John, really. I don't think we need to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm asking the man a question. If he doesn't want to give me the answer, I'm assuming he'll have sense enough to tell me so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suppose we just say that people anywhere aren't very well advised to have babies unless they can afford them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods slowly) Okay. Okay; it's a question of money. Money's always a good reason...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's hardly ever the real reason. What's the real reason? Wife talk you out of it, or what?

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS I can't tell you how pleased I am about the little Revolutionary Road place, Howard. Remember how dreary it looked all winter? All cold and dark and -- well, spooky. Creepy- crawly. And now whenever I drive past, it gives me such a lift to see it all perked up and spanking clean again, with lights in the windows. And do you know, I was just thinking, I've loved that little house for years, and the Braces are the first really suitable people I've ever found for it. Really nice, congenial people, I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS Well, except for the Wheelers, you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS Oh, I was very fond of the Wheelers but they always were a bit -- a bit whimsical, for my taste. A bit neurotic. I may not have stressed it, but they were often very trying people to deal with, in many ways. (MORE)

dialogue.raw_text: . GIVINGS (CONT'D) Actually, the main reason the little house has been so hard to sell is that they let it depreciate so dreadfully. Warped window frames, wet cellar, crayon marks on the walls, filthy smudges around all the--
